items.title: Update index.md

items.content_html:
Summary

Edited code examples, to convert sequence of two .then() functions, to a single one.

Motivation

According to the examples the developer can access all 'response' properties in the first .then(),
and the response.body data in the second .then(), separately.
With the suggested code the whole 'response' object is available in the first .then() block.
That is all response properties, together with the response.body.

Supporting details

Lots of developers do not use fetch API because of this exact issue.
They can not access together response properties and data in one code block.
The examples code confuses users, as it is obvious by the stackoverflow.com questions.

Related issues

Metadata

  • Adds a new document
  • Rewrites (or significantly expands) a document
  • Fixes a typo, bug, or other error
items.title: Examples code re-written with response.body stream converted to string.

items.content_html: See #12918 (comment). This reverts commit c980d6f. That change was wrong; while a key for a Map can be a number (or any other primitive, or even a function or object), a key for an Object can‚Äôt actually be a number. (In fact the point of the table in which this change was made is to contrast (a) the lack of type limitations on Map keys with (b) the limitation that Object keys can only by strings or symbols.)
items.title: Revert "Update ‚ÄúMap‚Äù doc to include a Number as a valid Object key (#12918)"

items.content_html:
This changes the slug for the Array.prototype.reduce() article to Web/JavaScript/Reference/Global_Objects/Array/reduce, for consistency with slugs for all other Array methods ‚Äî in particular, reduceRight(): Web/JavaScript/Reference/Global_Objects/Array/reduceRight

Below are the results of ripgrepping Global_Objects/Array slugs.

As can be seen in the results, the Array.prototype.reduce() article is the only one that doesn‚Äôt have a lowercase slug ‚Äî other than the Array() constructor article, whose slug should not be lowercased.

$ rg --no-filename "slug: Web/JavaScript/Reference/Global_Objects/Array/" | sort
slug: Web/JavaScript/Reference/Global_Objects/Array/@@iterator

items.content_html:
This PR contains a rewrite of the JS async module. It replaces #12525: this PR contains versions of the 2 articles in that PR, plus three new articles that should complete the module.

I'm marking this draft because it should be merged along with the corresponding update to the learning-area repo over in mdn/learning-area#453, and changes in either PR might mean we need changes in the other one. So let's not merge this until mdn/learning-area#453 is approved (and vice versa).

But it should be ready for review.

Before this PR, the module contained the following articles:

  1. General asynchronous programming concepts
  2. Introducing asynchronous JavaScript
  3. Cooperative asynchronous JavaScript: Timeouts and intervals
  4. Handling async operations gracefully with Promises
  5. Making asynchronous programming easier with async and await
  6. Choosing the right approach

For the reasons given in #12525, I thought I'd try rewriting this module and streamlining it. In this PR we have 5 articles:

  1. Introducing asynchronous JavaScript: conceptual introduction to async and why it matters, a bit about events and callbacks, and why they are problematic.
  2. How to use promises: how to work with promise-based APIs: promise chains, error handling, promise.all(), async/await. This is the central article: I think if there's one thing we want beginners to take away, it's how to use promise-based APIs and especially how to write promise chains.
  3. Implementing a promise-based API: quite short article going through creating promises.
  4. Introducing workers: a bit on threads and walk through using a worker.
  5. Assessment: Sequencing animations: a practical exercise to reinforce the lesson about using promises.

I'm hoping that this will be more digestible than what was there before and hope that I haven't jettisoned too much stuff.

Note that the links to example code won't work until mdn/learning-area#453 is merged, but you could see them at the wbamberg equivalent, such as https://wbamberg.github.io/learning-area/javascript/asynchronous/sequencing-animations/finished.
items.title: JS Learn area: async module rewrite

Summary

The role attribute was unnecessary in the example. With it, Google Talkback reads aloud the caption twice:

role=img -
A cow saying ... -
27 _ < I'm ... 27 _ < I'm ...
A cow saying ... A cow saying ...

Motivation

Quick

Supporting details

Thanks @9Nish4 for reporting
See also #12361 (comment)

Related issues

items.content_html:
popularities.json lists the Array article as one of our ten most-visited. So it merits some attention toward trying to make it as good a resource as possible for the many people coming by to read it. Thus this PR includes the following changes:

  • streamlines the article intro down to just the essential points
  • restructures the sections for a better information flow
  • adds prose introductions to all the existing code examples
  • gives all the examples linkable headings
  • rewrites the code of many examples, for greater clarity/consistency
  • makes various copy edits
items.title: Improve the Array article.
